children.name: DDD and event storming. Allen Holub lecture on O'Reily
Domain-Driven Design Distilled Vaugn
Distinction between domain and code
Map from domain to the architecture
Analyzing domain is designing the architecture.
Changes happen in the domain
Scope of change is mapped to the domain
Bounded Contexts
Large modular boundaries
Entitles - things that do work. Stand alone agents that do things within the context
Entities will talk to each other
Aggregate - group of entities. Changes within an aggregate don't leak out
If entitiese start talking across modular boundaries things get tricky.
Event storming is identifying events, entities and aggregates
There will be a Ubiquitous language in the boundary
Within different contexts there is little commonality
Change will typically happen within a bounded context
Orchestration
Synchronous services
You know who you are talking to and what they can do
Tightly couples the orchestrator and the service
Choreography
Use an event mode rather than services
Reactive services reduces coupling.
How do we recognise the events and entities in the system
CRC Card
Encapsulate on one card the things important about the entity
Responsibility. All the things it does are all concentrated on the same objective. (Not only do one thing)
Timesheet example:
Role
Actor
Stories
A short narrative - just what you expect. Short
Don't put too much information in too soon
Describes a user performing a domain process that results in a valuable outcome for that user
Needs to make something better
Stories are driven by the customer
If you have to write it down to remember it you are getting the details too soon
Flush the details out before implementation
Describes a users work, not yours
Logging in - not a story
Fill out a time sheet this is a story.
Epics not a group of stories, but a broad capability of the business as a whole
Requirements describes the program.
INVEST
INDEPENDENT
Implement in any order
NEGOTIABLE
Will change when you start implementing
VALUABLE
ESTIMABLE
This is a bit questionable
or Worthy of great respect
ESSENTIAL
SMALL
Should be able to do it in a day or two
TESTABLE
Keep user goals in mind
This will fundamentally effect what you do.
Worst story ever
As a user, I want to fill out a profile survey so that I can get personalized service. but this process shouldn't degrade my user experience
User - not a role
No one wants to do this
How can it not degrade my experience
What is the personalized service?
No user level problem being solved.
Splitting
When a story is too large, you wast time implementing less-valuable capabilities.
No more than a couple of days to implement.
Better to fail to compete a small story than a large one
Single acceptance test
Isolate components of workflow.
Do this to make stories smaller
https://agileforall.com/resources/how-to-split-a-user-story/
Event storming
Need to
Have a set of stories
Picked the most valuable one.
Understand the domain
Guessed what the entities are
This is an iterative process and initially will be wrong
Get business people and developers together.
Come up with an event model that will apply to one story at a time
Event, Something that happened in the business
Lay them out on a timeline
Works better if people are physical together.
Orange Note - Event
Blue Note - Action
Red Note - Question
Work products
Policies (rules)
Entity
As soon as you put the obvious events  up you realize there are many other events than need to be mapped.
You start putting the events and actions together. and put the other stuff on top
You then assign an entity to the events and actions - entity will be part of a context
Alberto Brandolini - leanpup
Things people do not who they are. The role is important

Employee:
Creates new time sheet as necessary and fills them out daily

Manager:
Approves (or challenges) Time Sheets for Employees in their group

Timesheet:
Tracks time spent by an employee working on a specific project

Accounting Dept:
Creates paychecks fore employee based on time sheet.
